data.title: Roughriders defence looks to return to form after loss to Elks
data.meta_description: After giving up an average of just 48 rushing yards per game in the first eight weeks, the Riders gave up 276 rushing yards against the Elks on Saturday
data.text:
Article content

The Saskatchewan Roughriders are hoping it was just a temporary leak.

Roughriders defence looks to return to form after loss to Elks Back to video

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

After being the CFL’s stingiest run defence through the first seven games of the season, the Green and White allowed 276 rushing yards in a 42-31 loss to the Edmonton Elks on Saturday, with running back Javon Leake generating 169 of those yards.

“We’re the top run defence in the league,” said Riders’ defensive back Rolan Milligan Jr. “That’s not like us.

Article content

“They just executed and took advantage of us not executing.”

Through Week 8 of the season, Saskatchewan had given up an average of just 48 rushing yards against per game, limiting top running backs like Winnipeg’s Brady Oliveira, Toronto’s Ka’Deem Carey and B.C.’s William Stanback along the way.

Then entered Leake and mobile quarterback Tre Ford, who picked up 46 rushing yards on five carries in his first start of the season. Backup running back Justin Rankin also chipped in with 60 yards on 10 carries as Edmonton ran all over Saskatchewan.

“We just weren’t doing our job and being where we’re supposed to be,” said Milligan. “We’ve just got to get the corrections and when it’s time to play, just got to execute.”

Having lost two games in a row, Saskatchewan still sits in a tie atop the West Division with a 5-3 record alongside the B.C. Lions, who are up 1-0 in the season series between the two teams.

The Riders will now look to right the ship in Week 10 against the 5-2 Ottawa Redblacks on Thursday night (5:30 p.m., TSN) in the nation’s capital.

The Redblacks, who are 4-0 at home this season led by mobile quarterback Dru Brown, are coming off a bye week after beating the Calgary Stampeders 33-6 the week prior.

Article content

Injury news

Despite returning to practice for the first time since suffering a knee injury in the third game the season, quarterback Trevor Harris has been ruled out of Thursday’s game in Ottawa.

Linebacker Jameer Thurman (elbow) also won’t play this week, alongside receiver KeeSean Johnson (head), offensive lineman Ryan Sceviour (elbow) and linebacker Melique Straker (hamstring), who were all injured against the Elks.

Running back A.J. Ouellette (hip) and offensive lineman Jacob Brammer (hamstring) will also be forced to miss another week

Council retires

After starting at right tackle last week, American offensive lineman Brandon Council has announced his retirement on Tuesday.

Council — who was activated off the suspended list a couple weeks ago — was filling in for the injured Jacob Brammer, who was replacing the injured Jermarcus Hardrick.

Last season, the 27-year-old played 12 games for the Riders before accepting a job at Auburn University this off-season, where he is set to return to.

Riders add two

The Riders also added two players to the roster this week with the additions of Canadian offensive lineman Braydon Noll and American defensive lineman Eric Black.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

The 6-foot-5, 297-pound Noll previously spent time with the Toronto Argonauts after being drafted by the club 35th overall in 2022. He played four games for the Argos in his rookie season.

Meanwhile, the 6-foot-4, 247-pound Black joins the Green and White after beginning the season with the Edmonton Elks, although he did not appear in a game.

tshire@postmedia.com
